clinical_study.brief_title: Comparative Effects of Variable Pressure Support, NAVA and PAV
clinical_study.official_title: Comparative Effects of Variable Pressure Support, Neurally Adjusted Ventilatory Assist (NAVA) and Proportional Assist Ventilation (PAV) on the Variability of the Breathing Pattern and on Patient Ventilator Interaction

lead_sponsor.agency: Association pour le Développement et l'Organisation de la Recherche en Pneumologie et sur le Sommeil

clinical_study.source: Association pour le Développement et l'Organisation de la Recherche en Pneumologie et sur le Sommeil

brief_summary.textblock:
Experimental animal data suggest that increasing breathing pattern variability in mechanical ventilation could be beneficial. Variable ventilation can be induced through the following modes: Neurally Adjust Ventilatory Assist (NAVA), Proportional Assist Ventilation (PAV) and Variable-Pressure Support Ventilation (V-PSV). These modes have not yet been compared to each other. Pilot observations in our department suggest a feasibility in patients.
The objectives of the study are to compare the impact of PSV, NAVA, PAV and V-PSV on the variability of the breathing pattern, patient-ventilator asynchrony, risk of lung overdistension, gas exchange, and repartition of ventilation.

detailed_description.textblock:
Cross-over, prospective, randomized controlled monocentric trial . Patients on pressure support ventilation will be ventilated with PSV, NAVA, PAV, and V-PSV (in a randomized sequence).
In each mode the level of assistance will be set to achieve a similar tidal volume of 6-8 ml/kg.
The following data will be measured and recorded: airway flow and pressure, electrical activity of the diaphragm (EAdi), blood gases, electrical impedance tomography, end tidal partial pressure in carbon dioxide (PEtCO2).
Will be calculated: the coefficient of variation (CV, standard deviation (SD)/mean) of the peak pressure (Ppeak), EAdi and of the main descriptors of the breathing pattern, the prevalence of the main patient-ventilator asynchronies, the prevalence of tidal volume (VT) >10ml/kg, ventrodorsal repartition of ventilation and inhomogeneity index, dead space

primary_outcome.measure: Coefficient of variation of the tidal volume (VT)
primary_outcome.description: Coefficient of variation (standard deviation/mean) of the tidal volume (VT)

primary_outcome.measure: Coefficient of variation of the respiratory rate (RR)
primary_outcome.description: Coefficient of variation (standard deviation/mean) of the respiratory rate (RR)

primary_outcome.measure: Coefficient of variation of the inspiratory time (Ti)
primary_outcome.description: Coefficient of variation (standard deviation/mean) of the inspiratory time (Ti)

primary_outcome.measure: Coefficient of variation of the electrical activity of the diaphragm (EAdi)
primary_outcome.description: Coefficient of variation (standard deviation/mean) of the electrical activity of the diaphragm (EAdi)

primary_outcome.measure: Coefficient of variation of the maximal inspiratory pressure (Ppeak)
primary_outcome.description: Coefficient of variation (standard deviation/mean) of the maximal inspiratory pressure (Ppeak)

secondary_outcome.description: asynchrony index (composite outcome, that includes double triggering, auto triggering and ineffective efforts) )

secondary_outcome.measure: Safety from lung overdistension, assessed by the proportion of tidal volumes (VT) >10 ml/kg

secondary_outcome.description: Ratio of arterial oxygen partial pressure to fractional inspired oxygen (PaO2/FiO2), arterial carbon dioxide pressure (PaCO2)

secondary_outcome.measure: Repartition of ventilation measured by electrical impedance tomography
Dead space to tidal volume ratio (Vd/Vt)
secondary_outcome.description: Vd/Vd, is a ratio between two volumes

arm_group.description: This is a crossover study in which each patient will be ventilated in the following modes of mechanical ventilation: Pressure Support Ventilation (PSV), Neurally Adjusted Ventilator Assist (NAVA), Proportional assist ventilation (NAVA) and variable Pressure Support Ventilation (Variable-PSV), in a randomised order.

intervention.description: Each patient enrolled in the study will be ventilated in all the following modes: PSV, NAVA, PAV and variable PSV

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patient on mechanical ventilation for >48 h
- estimated duration of mechanical ventilation >24h
- hemodynamic stability
Exclusion Criteria:
- pregnancy
- impossibility to insert an EAdi catheter
- neuromuscular disease, phrenic nerve lesions
